title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness when hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, where wages paid by a qualified employer are exempt from taxes for services performed during that year. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" defines a qualified employer as any employer other than the United States, states, local governments, or their instrumentalities. A qualified individual is someone who starts employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certifies not working more than 40 hours in the 60 days before starting, and is not employed by the qualified employer. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" defines a qualified employer as any employer other than the United States, states, local governments, or their instrumentalities. A qualified individual is someone who starts employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certifies not working more than 40 hours in the 60 days before starting, and is not employed to replace another employee unless the other employee left voluntarily or for cause. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" excludes certain wages paid to qualified individuals by qualified employers from being considered as part of wages for a specific period. Additionally, funds are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions caused by the amendments. The amendments made by the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" aim to replicate transfers to the Trust Fund and apply to wages paid after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010 increases the current year business credit by $1,000 for each retained worker employed for at least 52 consecutive weeks with wages paid during the last 26 weeks. The business credit increases by $1,000 for each retained worker employed for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages equaling 80% in the last 26 weeks compared to the first 26 weeks.
